objects.name: All_Changes
objects.search_constraints: tag=change NOT (object_category=file OR object_category=directory OR object_category=registry)

fields.name: action
fields.comment: The action performed on the resource.

fields.name: change_type
fields.comment: The type of change, such as filesystem or AAA (authentication, authorization, and accounting).

fields.name: command
fields.comment: The command that initiated the change.

fields.name: dest
fields.comment: The resource where change occurred. You can alias this from more specific fields not included in this data model, such as dest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.

fields.name: dvc
fields.comment: The device that reported the change, if applicable, such as a FIP or CIM server. You can alias this from more specific fields not included in this data model, such as dvc_host, dvc_ip, or dvc_name.

fields.name: object
fields.comment: Name of the affected object on the resource (such as a router interface, user account, or server volume).

fields.name: object_attrs
fields.comment: The attributes that were updated on the updated resource object, if applicable.

fields.name: object_category
fields.comment: Generic name for the class of the updated resource object. Expected values may be specific to an app.

fields.name: object_id
fields.comment: The unique updated resource object ID as presented to the system, if applicable (for instance, a SID, UUID, or GUID value).

fields.name: object_path
fields.comment: The path of the modified resource object, if applicable (such as a file, directory, or volume).

fields.name: result
fields.comment: The vendor-specific result of a change, or clarification of an action status. For instance, status=failure may be accompanied by result=blocked by policy or result=disk full. result is a string. Please use a msg_severity_id field (not included in the data model) for severity ID fields that are integer data types.

fields.name: result_id
fields.comment: A result indicator for an action status.

fields.name: src
fields.comment: The resource where the change was originated. You can alias this from more specific fields not included in the data model, such as src_host, src_ip, or src_name.

fields.name: status
fields.comment: Status of the update.

fields.name: tag
fields.comment: This automatically generated field is used to access tags from within data models. Add-on builders do not need to populate it.

fields.name: user
fields.comment: The user or entity performing the change. For account changes, this is the account that was changed (see src_user for user or entity performing the change).

fields.name: user_agent
fields.comment: The user agent through which the request was made, such as Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_6) or aws-cli/2.0.0 Python/3.7.4 Darwin/18.7.0 botocore/2.0.0dev4.

fields.name: user_name
fields.comment: The user name of the user or entity performing the change. For account changes, this is the account that was changed this is the account that was changed (see src_user_name).

fields.name: user_type
fields.comment: The type of the user involved in the event or who initiated the event, such as IAMUser, Admin, or System. For account management events, this should represent the type of the user changed by the request.

fields.name: vendor_account
fields.comment: The account that manages the user that initiated the request. The account represents the organization, or a Cloud customer or a Cloud account.

fields.name: vendor_region
fields.comment: The account that manages the user that initiated the request. The account represents the organization, or a Cloud customer or a Cloud account.

fields.name: vendor_product
fields.comment: The vendor and product or service that detected the change. This field can be automatically populated by vendor and product fields in your data.

fields.name: dest_nt_domain
fields.comment: The NT domain of the destination, if applicable.

fields.name: src_nt_domain
fields.comment: The NT domain of the source, if applicable.

fields.name: src_user
fields.comment: For account changes, the user or entity performing the change.

fields.name: src_user_type
fields.comment: For account management events, this should represent the type of the user changed by the request.

fields.name: src_user_name
fields.comment: For account changes, the user name of the user or entity performing the change.

fields.name: image_id
fields.comment: For create instance events, this field represents the image ID used for creating the instance such as the OS, applications, installed libraries, and more.

fields.name: instance_type
fields.comment: For create instance events, this field represents the type of instance to build such as the combination of CPU, memory, storage, and network capacity.

fields.name: dest_ip_range
fields.comment: For network events, the outgoing traffic for a specific destination IP address range. Specify a single IP address or an IP address range in CIDR notation. For example, 203.0.113.5 or 203.0.113.5/32.

fields.name: dest_port_range
fields.comment: For network events, this field represents destination port or range. For example, 80 or 8000 - 8080 or 80,443.

fields.name: direction
fields.comment: For network events, this field represents whether the traffic is inbound or outbound.

fields.name: protocol
fields.comment: This field represents the protocol for the network event rule.

fields.name: rule_action
fields.comment: For network events, this field represents whether to allow or deny traffic.

fields.name: src_ip_range
fields.comment: For network events, this field represents the incoming traffic from a specific source IP address or range. Specify a single IP address or an IP address range in CIDR notation.

fields.name: src_port_range
fields.comment: For network events, this field represents source port or range. For example, 80 or 8000 - 8080 or 80,443

fields.name: device_restarts
fields.comment: Monitor all infrastructure device restarts.
